etymologies: late 18th century (in an earlier sense). Apparently the reflex of a borrowing from early Scandinavian (compare Old Icelandic síma, sími, Norwegian sime, Old Swedish simi (Swedish regional simme), Old Danish simae, syme (Danish sime, now chiefly regional), all in the sense ‘rope’)

definitions: A rope made from twisted straw; specifically such a rope used to fasten down the thatch on a haystack.
